Replies.Reply: Everyone's got that one summer when they were a kid... a summer so perfect, that it stays with them forever. It stays caught in time, like Camelot.
Everybody sometime in their life has met a real live hero.

They're not exactly a dime a dozen, but there's plenty of people who've done real great things. But hardly anyone has ever met a certified Legend, because most of them are dead before they get voted one.
So, to actually be there at the moment one gets made... well, forget about it. It never happens. Almost never...
...to the all-time, hands down, complete and undisputed Legend that ever lived.
In any language, in any country, in any world. The Sultan of Swat. The King of Clout. The Great Bambino.
...The Babe.
There's never been anyone greater than The Babe. And when he called his famous full count homerun in the 1932 world series, he made sure he'd live forever.
would've happened. Weird thing was, before I moved to the neighborhood, I had no idea who he was. And he played a game I knew nothing about.

Fourteen years later, after The Babe was gone, there was another guy who had something to do with the legend getting made too. A guy who set a record that summer that was so awesome, some people still don't believe it.
I moved to the neighborhood about a month before school let out. I was from another state, and didn't have a single friend in a thousand miles.
It was a lousy way to end up the 5th grade, 'cause I had zip time to make friends before summer. And that's about where it all started...
Everyone but the Timmons twins lived on my new block.
They lived in a house by the sandlot and had the world's greatest tree house, because their dad was a contractor.
Even before I knew any of them I envied that tree house...
...later, it would become second only to Cape Canaveral as a command post for history.

When I moved in that summer, I'd never played baseball, but it wasn't too tough figuring out who these guys' heroes were. So, after a week of watching... I figured baseball seemed like the best way to get in with them.
My real dad died when I was just a little kid. My mom married Bill a year before we moved to the neighborhood.
At the time, he and I were still getting used to each other.

They never kept score. They never chose sides. They never even really stopped playing the game... it just went on forever. Everyday they picked up right where they left off the day before. It was an endless "dream game."
There was only 8 of them, so they didn't have a whole team. It didn't matter though... Benny was so good he took everyone's position when it was there ups.
I didn't know any of that then... I just knew they were having the time of their lives and I wanted to be a part of it.
Everyone knew Benny was different.
Even though he seemed like a regular guy, he wasn't. Benny was special, and he was loyal.

When they'd all tried out for youth league, they'd all made it. But when they found out they'd have to play on different teams, Benny told 'em that if they couldn't play together, they shouldn't play at all. So, they stayed together.
So, the only person that ever felt sorry for me 'cause I was such a weenie was Benjamin Franklin Rodriguez.
Even though neither of us knew it at the time, we were connected. Like I had been born for just that one moment, when I would perform the world's all-
I had no idea who they were talking about. But there was no way I could let them know that... so, I lied.
Everyday, first thing, we'd all pick a card from what we called "The Dugout."
It was just a shoe box, but whoever we picked, we got to be when it was our ups. One day, when Ham took his pick a little too seriously, the guys let me in on the world's most terrifying secret...
I learned that more than a 150 baseballs had gone over that fence... and not one of them was ever seen again. Even when some brave kid worked up enough courage to peek over the fence.
Because, when they went over, they vanished.
I knew it was true, because when I looked down in there, I didn't see a single... solitary... one.
Benny would've played ball all day and all night... rain shine, tidal wave, whatever, it didn't matter. Baseball was the only thing he cared about and everything else was just a waste of time.

But, of all the things we ever did besides baseball, goin' to the pool was what he tolerated best. Even though none of us had ever seen a Playboy magazine - which we constantly lied about - we figured the pool was the next best thing to being there.
It wasn't the Pool Honeys like we said, 'cause if any one of them had come up to any one of us, we'd of peed our pants.
We went for... the Lifeguard.
And one day, it became too much for Michael "Squints" Palledorous. And he did the most desperate thing any of us had ever seen.

Michael "Squints" Palledorous walked a little taller that day. And we had to tip our hats to him. He was lucky she hadn't beat the crap out of him. We wouldn't have blamed her. What he'd done was sneaky, rotten and low.
And cool.
Not another one among us would've ever, even for a million dollars, had the guts to put the move on the Lifeguard.
Besides The Great Bambino, who I still had no clue about, Benny had one living hero.
A guy that would break the stolen bases record that year that had stood for as many years as there were baseball's lost to The Beast.
Maury Wills became a hero for what he did.
Benny... would become a Legend.
There was only one nightgame a year.
We all knew Benny was different. We knew that he was gonna go on to bigger and better games.
Because everytime we stopped to watch the sky that night like regular kids, Benny was there to call us back.
For him, baseball wasn't just a game.
...baseball was life.
Once we got over trying to be big shots, we just stuck to what we could handle, and swore off the hard stuff forever.
We all expected something to happen right then... during that game. What we had just witnessed was bordering on the supernatural... we knew that greater hands than ours were at work.
And it happened alright.
It happened right in front of our noses... and we didn't even know it.
It was salt in an open wound. Even my own mom, who was only a grown-up girl, knew who Babe Ruth was.
I was dead meat. I knew it. They knew it. We had thought that those cards Benny had gotten meant that something great was going to happen.
We had absolutely no idea what the hell we were gonna do. So things started primitively.
Yeah-Yeah grew two feet in our eyes after that. There was no stinkin' way any of us would've showed back up, if we'd loaded our drawers.
Yeah-Yeah did. He showed back up and got right to work, like nothing ever happened.
- Yeah-Yeah returns across the sandlot and goes up into the treehouse.
My life was over. Just as Bill had finally warmed up to me, and asked me to be the man of the house, I had to knock a priceless chunk of history into the clutches of a monster. Great.
It was weird that Benny said Babe Ruth was like the Hercules of baseball, and then The Beast's name turned out to be Hercules.
It was also strange that Mr. Mertle had a Murderers' Row ball to replace the one signed by The Babe.
Some people might say that it was all a coincidence... but looking back at it now, it seems like everything was connected, just like me and Benny.
It was like we were a part of the same myth as The Babe... the Myth of Baseball.
That was the last summer that we all got to play together.
But it would stay with us forever.
After Benny pickled the Beast, his reputation spread all over town. From then on he was known as Benny "The Juet" Rodriguez.
The nickname stuck with him the rest of his life.
Safe!
SAFE! SAFE! SAFE!
comes in home - cutting him off. He's caught in a pickle.
Ham, it ain't really.
Do I look stupid?
Let's play.
who connects big. CRACK!
is the only one that isn't laughing. He stares the others down.
I bet not one of you knows how The Babe got his nickname.
I knew it. You're all full of crap.

Nobody liked him there. The bigger guys picked on him all the time. And when they messed with him he couldn't fight back, 'cause he was just... like scared. So when they messed with him, he cried about it.
He cried... so they called him The Babe.
How ya think that kid just felt?
- God, whadda jerk!
Gonna go play some ball. Need a extra guy. Wanna go?
Why not? Doncha like baseball?
But what?
That's okay.
I got a extra one.
And chaw and stuff, ya know?
You dip chaw?
The King of Krash!
So, Scott, this is Ken DeNunez; Alan McClennan, we call him Yeah-Yeah; Hamilton Porter, we call him Ham; Tommy and Timmy Timmons, Bertram Grover Weeks, and Mike "Squints" Palledorus.
He's Scott Smalls.
He's gonna play with us. He makes nine. Now we got a team.
'Cause there's eight of us, and he makes nine.
With nine Guys we got a whole team.
Oh yeah, Squints, and you're Willie freakin' Mays. You catch like a dork -
- and you run like a duck, Yeah- Yeah.
- part-a the game.
How come he don't get to be?
You take right field, Smalls.
Uh, over there.
takes home plate worried: "Maybe the kid is a weenie."
Get two.
Smalls! Get one!
trots out after him.
Hey, you can throw it ya know.
You think too much. I bet you get straight A's and shit, huh?
This is baseball, you're not supposed to think, you're just supposed to play.
You ever have a paper route?
Throw it like you chuck a paper. When your arm gets here... just let go of it.
Just let go.
Don't worry. Just stand there and stick your glove in the air. I'll take care of it.
Smalls, get one!
gives him a "Thumbs Up." The significance of this is only outweighed by his sudden fear, when...
Keep it.
gives Scotty another "Thumbs Up." The kid's in.
Bingo! Maury Wills!
You can't go back there, Smalls.
Game's over. We'll get a new one tomorrow. Just forget it. We'll never see it again.
Go over there, real slow, and be quiet.
You did, man.
gulps.
What took you so long?! We been here forever already!
- naw, don't, man. He's just mad he didn't think of it.
Come on, don't be wimpy.
Vote then. Everyone that wants to be a can't-hack-it panty waist, and wear their momma's bra, raise your hand.
Fine. Be like that. So what're we gonna do then?
Oh, man...
Yeah she does. She knows exactly what she's doing.

gives Scotty "Thumbs Up." Just as  SCOTTY'S  gonna throw the ball back, he shivers, noticing that the sun has fallen to a precise declination; its rays focused behind the glowing green fiberglass of  MR. MERTLE'S FENCE  against which a hulking black form rises in the backyard...
Play us and you'll find out why, Phillips.
Yeah. For now. Let's go.
Who?
Naw he ain't, not yet.
leans forward seriously.
No... not yet.
watches intensely.
He's... gonna... go... riiiight...
smiles to himself.
Get your glove, c'mon.
Nightgame!
Knocks dirt from his p.f. flyers. Twirls the bat. Cocks it back. Coils up 'round his back leg.
cranks one to kingdom come.
marches over. The gang follows.
What'id you say, crapface?
Somebody get it!
That's one. Get used to it.
Crack! Boom! Outta here! You see the looks on their faces? Did ya? It was like, "Duh... so that's how you play baseball."
Smooth.
staring down at the cards in his hands. He slowly shuffles them top to bottom... top to bottom.
picks up a bat.
We gotta play. I gotta play right now, guys. Right now.
Naw, it ain't.
All's it means is that we can't play no more. It's only noon, and I just blew the whole day for us.
Anybody got any money?
Then it ain't okay, 'cause now we can't play no more.
What, you got 98 extra cents just layin' around at home, Smalls?
who catches it.
Bitchin'. Your ball, your ups.
tosses DeNunez the ball on his way by.
backpeddles.
It's outta here! Who's got the big bat now, boys!
It was a great shot, but forget about it... game's over. We'll get another ball.
Sure we do. You feel bad 'cause you belted a homer, and now we can't play no more.
Yeah. Smalls, Babe Ruth is the greatest baseball player that ever lived. People say he was less than a God, but more than a man. Ya know... like Hercules or somethin'.
The ball that you just aced to The Beast is worth... well, more than your whole life.
When does your old man get home from work?
Okay, we need 98 cents. So, everybody spread out and find some soda bottles and cash 'em in. We need a new baseball.
It doesn't matter what it looks like.
Is Doby Gillis a dork? Anybody got any bright ideas?
Sorry, Smalls. It was a good idea anyway.
Here. Put these on.
Oh, ah, nuthin', ya know, just For, ah... Altitude leveling And stuff. Put it on.
runs for it.
I got it! I got it!
We can't get it back, Babe.
I'm sorry.
M - M - Mom?...
Who's there?!
B - B - But, you're...
You're really him. You're The Babe.
Yeah.
Yeah, right.
Wait! I can't.
Go into that backyard.
There's a Beast back there.
A giant gorilla-dog-thing that ate one kid already.
Sure, yeah, five Maury Wills all in the same pack.
About a zillion to one.
Yeah, but what?
You mean, I should hop that fence -
Sure, the greatest most famous and legendary home run of all time.
Sure ya did, Babe.
I had a dream. Get dressed. We're goin' to the sandlot.
Yeah I do, Smalls. I have to.
leaves scrambling footprints. He slides - grabs the ball -
springs off the ground. He's on the fence.
YOWWWWW!
OOOOH SSSSHIT!
comes sliding AT US across the waxed stage floor - from under the movie screen. He slides off the stage - into midair -
zips under the banner - runs through - grabs a Coke like a long distance runner.
rips into the square. He rubba-leg zigzags, nimbly avoiding everything and everyone.
zips through the MARCHING BAND - ducking trombone slides -
Sandlot!
just runs. He runs as if a big dog was chasing him. He lurches a step - RIP! A pants pocket flaps from an incisor.
LOOK OUT!
jets upward, leaving smashed green fiberglass footsteps -
who pushes off the top of the fence.
Oh noooooo!
holding the Babe Ruth Autograph up high like a trophy.
I GOT IT!
We can play forever now.
- we hit a baseball into your yard.
Yeah.
Well, that's really nice of you... but this ball really is signed by The Babe.
This one really is too... and all the rest of the '27 Yankees.
Oh my God - Murderers' Row.
Lou Gehrig...
PICKLE!
Great, I'm dyin' a thirst and you pee me out!
Then switch with me.
Fifth grade's history, man. A hundred days, man. A Hundred days of baseball.

Hey! Throw the ball back!
That kid's got the gaw'damn panty-
Easy, 'cause of the way he looked like a little kid face.

What?...
What did he say?
That wimpy deer?

Hank Aaron. I'm up.
mercilessly.
takes a Ruthian cut at it. CONNECTS to deep right.
Forever even.
Wanna s'more?
No. You wanna s'more?
First you take the graham - you put the chocolate on the graham, Hershey's of course - you hold the chocolate on the graham while you roast the mallow-
-then when the mallow's flamin', ya stuff it on the chocolate and cover it with the other end.
Then, you scarf.
Kinda messy... Good though.
You did, man.
Liar! It was only one.

- yeah it is! He got eaten!
Whatever goes over that fence... stays there.
I am holdin' you back Squints.
Sonavabitch!

I can't take it no more, Benny. I'm bakin' like a toasted cheeser!
Hamonball!

Eee! Eee! Eee! Oh! Oh! Oh!

Shut up, blockhead.
Hey, who d'ya think'd win in a fight, King Kong or Godzilla?

Come on! We'll take you on right here, right now! Come on! Right now!
Watch yer mouth, jerk!
Asshole!
Butt sniffer!

YOU PLAY BALL LIKE A GIRL!
You heard me.
Count on it, pee drinkin' craphead.
PLAAAAAAAY BALLLLLLLL!

Ah, you're out.
Geez, Smalls... I s'pose you don't who The Babe is either. It's chaw. Plug.

Juicy.

Batter up!

What did he say?!
The Great Bambino!

- somebody slap him quick! We're losin' him!

HELP! I'M LOSIN' HIM!

WE'RE WAITING...

- if you were thinkin' you wouldn't a thought that!

And when The Ham heard it he barfed up two bags of marshmallows.
So stay away from the door... you might fall out. And don't sit on your sleeping bag... you could shit your pants.
Now, quiet...
The legend of The Beast goes back a long time... before any of us could pick up a baseball. Back to a place called Mertle's Acres.
The Beast belongs to Mr. Mertle, the guy that used to own Mertle's Acres Junkyard. And nobody's ever seen him since the day it happened...
Mertle's Acres was a bitchin' place, that had everything you could ever imagine.
And he did. And he liked it.
The Beast was the most perfect junkyard dog that ever lived... a true killing machine.
After awhile, the police started getting phone calls from people, reporting all the missing thieves. The ones The Beast had killed... it added up to about 37 guys.
The Beast was good at his guarddog job. Too good. So the cops said he had to be retired. But he didn't have to be killed or nothin', on account of there was no evidence... no bones...
The police told Mr. Mertle that if wanted to keep The Beast, he hadda lock him in his backyard, so he could never get out.
They said... until forever.
is proud of his story prowess.
And so... The Beast sits there under that lean-to, dreaming about the time when he can break the chain and get out... dreaming of the time when he can chase and kill again.
Davy "The Toad" Stodenrous.
- oh, yeah?... Come here. Stick your head out the window and look down.
You bet he is.
It becomes the property of The Beast...
spits into his palm and rubs the ball to get the shine off.
can only manage a totally embarrassing goofy grin.
Shut up, I wasn't!
Hold me back! Hold me back!
Oh, yeah. Well, lemme go then.
Face it, Benny. It's not a fit day out for man nor beast. We gotta call it for the day.
is suddenly afflicted.
I've swum here every summer of my adult life... and every summer there she is.
Lotioning... oiling... smiling.
I - can't - take - this - no - more!
holds his nose. Takes the deep leap. Hits the water and...

Benny, man, are we gonna let 'em get away with that?!
Not possible. He's so big that fallin' off the Empire State's just like us fallin' off a roof... he's alive.

- well, he's real right?
And he's still out there somewhere right?
See, there's just somethings that are.
Tangy.
Let's ride.

A Brooks Robinson and a Koufax. Pretty good.
Benny, whad -
Oh, my God...
Oh geez... Oh geez. I - I don't believe it. Maury Wills just stole 80 bases!
It's a miracle, Smalls. A damn miracle.
C'mon, Benny, maybe two, three guys in history have ever busted the guts out of a ball. That's what the omen was.
in center. It's gonna be short! Squints sprints - Willy Mays basket catch. He throws to DeNunez.

Whadda you mean it wasn't your ball?
Smalls... listen to me. This is a matter of life and death.
Where did your old man get that ball?
Some lady?...
But it was signed by Babe Ruth!
He ain't gonna buy that, Benny. It doesn't look anything like the Babe's signature.
I have no idea.
Are you outta your mind?! Mr. Mertle is the meanest old man that ever lived!
We need to assess the situation!
First we survey the enemy's environment, then we make note of the surrounding terrain.
I heard that on "Combat." Let's just look out the window.
A-okay. Roger, affirmative. Initiate retreival suction.
We have suction! Pull it up! PULL IT UP!
heads. The vacuums explode. Foggy clouds of dust pour out of the treehouse. Squints appears. He's battleship grey.
We've been going about this all wrong.
Therefore, we tunnel. The Beast will never expect it.

That thing with the nuts and bolts and tiny wrenches that you can build junk out of?

This way! Shortcut!

All your moms wear boxers!
has been watching nearby.

Yeah-yeah, too cruel.
Don't-know, but that's the deep end, and Squints can't swim!
Yeah-yeah, wait a sec, maybe they'll do a movie someday and we'll find out.
Yeah-yeah, here he comes. He's gonna steal second.

Yeah-yeah, it's pretty crappy.

Thanks. I needed that.

Hey-hey, don't blame me! I didn't hit the ball over there, man!

Okay-okay, I'm right over it. Let me down - slow!
plummets.

Hail Mary Father who art star light twinkle twinkle hey diddle diddle -

the 8 guys forging ahead. He follows them.
with a holed box of detergent powder.

Replies.Reply: in left field - painted green and lettered "The Green Monster."
remains undercover, but he's bustin' to join in.
Sorry, Mom.
I know - but it's just nighttime.
No.
'Cause I'm still "new."
None mothers I guess.
'Kay.

Mom? Do you think Bill - I mean Dad -
Um, Dad - sorry, I mean Bill, remember you promised you'd teach me to play catch?
Well, could you teach me?
Okay. Great. Thanks.
panics. Runs back inside and...
sound of the hardball, SNAPPING CLEANLY in the oily leather of their gloves.
continues around the perimeter, trying to be seen and become invisible. He goes unwittingly CLOSER TO those green fiberglass panels.
tracks it, frozen stiff. Scared shitless. At the past possible moment, he throws his arms over his face and ducks...
hits his butt. The ball rolls a bit. Comes to an "I-dare-
'Kay, I'll get it!
Don't be a goofus - don't be a goofus -
who snatches up the ball and back-pedals 10 feet.
walks away... crying.
My life is over.
Sorry...
He's too busy, Mom.
Um, Da -
- I mean, Bill. Could we... I mean could you, like you said - teach me to catch today?
Okay, thanks.
Mom, it's okay -
Mom, really -
stands ready to "learn" on the other side of the yard.
Yeah, okay, I think so.
Darn. Sorry.
Here.
Okay. I'm ready.
Darn. My glove got -
But my glove -
'Kay.
Okay.
sticks his glove up.
right in the eye.
- just took my eye off the ball, Mom.
slowly waves back.
Naw. Thanks.
Oh. Yeah. But, ah...
But my glove's busted. So, ya know, I can't go. Thanks, though.
Mom! I'm gonna go play some ball!
Thanks. Cool glove.
Yeah.
Sure. A'course.
Who's that?
Oh! The Great Bambino! Of course. I thought you said The Great Bambi.
Ah, yeah - I guess. Sorry.
Hi.
standing off by himself, kinda lost. Benny comes over.
Right. Okay. Ah... where exactly is that?
who raises the glove, and skippers around, as if he were tracking a falling leaf. The ball lands 5 feet behind him.
runs to the ball, is about to throw... runs it in to DeNunez instead.
Here. Sorry, sorry.
runs back to right field. Ready again - a game kid.
No, I can't... I don't know how.
Um, thanks for taking me here... but I think better go.
No, I got a B once. Actually it was an A minus.
But it shoulda been a B.
Uh, I helped a guy one time.
Wait - how do I catch it?
sees it coming. Stands there stiffly. Sticks his glove up, closes his eyes.
Please, catch it. Please, catch it.
glimpses something.
Thanks.
Wait, here - your glove.
Mickey Mou - ah, Mantle.
